QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing the \( 5 \) plants with these heights:
\( 24 \mathrm{~cm}, 17 \mathrm{~cm}, 42 \mathrm{~cm}, 26 \mathrm{~cm}, 13 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Tom says if all the plants were cut in half, the range wouldn't change.
Katie says if all the plants grew by \( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \) each, the range wouldn't change.
Who do you agree with?
ConstructName: Calculate the range from a list of data
SubjectName: Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data
MisconceptionName: Believes if you changed all values by the same proportion the range would not change

QuestionText:

QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing related calculations
Tom says if you know that \( 3748+426=4174 \), then \( 3748+427 \) must equal \( \mathbf{4 1 7 5} \)

Katie says if you know that \( 3748-426=3322 \), then \( 3748 \) - \( 427 \) must equal \( \mathbf{3 3 2 3} \)
Who is correct?
ConstructName: Given the solution to one problem, deduce the answer to a related problem using the same operation
MisconceptionName: Does not realise that adding a larger number gives a larger answer

QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing related calculations
Tom says if you know that \( 3748+426=4174 \), then \( 3748+427 \) must equal \( \mathbf{4 1 7 5} \)

Katie says if you know that \( 3748-426=3322 \), then \( 3748 \) - \( 427 \) must equal \( \mathbf{3 3 2 3} \)
Who is correct?
ConstructName: Given the solution to one problem, deduce the answer to a related problem using the same operation
MisconceptionName: Does not realise that subtracting a larger number will give a smaller answer

QuestionText:
Water is poured into a glass at a constant rate.

This graph shows how the depth \( (d) \) of water in a glass changes over time \( (t) \).

Which of the following glasses is this most likely to be the graph of? ![A depth-time graph which is a curve starting at (0, 0), with a steep gradient to begin with but then the gradient decreases and the graph levels off to almost horizontal.]()

CorrectAnswerText: ![A shape that looks like a beaker. It has a circular base, with sloped edges up to a larger circular face at the top.]()
WrongAnswerText: ![A cylinder sitting on one of its circular faces.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not interpret a sloping gradient as a change in rate

QuestionText:
A vegetarian restaurant wants to know people's eating habits
\( 50 \) people in Town \( A \) are asked if they eat meat. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Town A } \\
\hline Do you eat meat? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 39 \) \\
\hline No & \( 11 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} \( 200 \) people in Town B are asked if they eat meat. \begin{tabular}{|cc|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Town B } \\
\hline Do you eat meat? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 143 \) \\
\hline No & \( 57 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which results are more reliable?
ConstructName: Compare relative frequencies in order to determine which prediction is likely to be more reliable
MisconceptionName: Does not know that sample size affects reliability

QuestionText:
The table shows the summary statistics from some girls and boys who took a test.
Who performed the most consistently? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Gender & Mean & Range \\
\hline Girls & \( 75 \) & \( 20 \) \\
\hline Boys & \( 60 \) & \( 40 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
ConstructName: Compare sets of data using the range
SubjectName: Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data
CorrectAnswerText: The girls because their range is lower
WrongAnswerText: The boys because their mean is lower
MisconceptionName: Thinks a lower average means the data is more consistent

QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}3 x-2 y=8 \\ 3 x+y=14\end{array} \) Tom says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Katie says if you subtract the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct?
ConstructName: Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable
MisconceptionName: Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we add the equations.

QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}3 x-2 y=8 \\ 3 x+y=14\end{array} \) Tom says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Katie says if you subtract the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct?
ConstructName: Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable
MisconceptionName: When solving simultaneous equations thinks that identical terms in given equations can be eliminated by either adding or subtracting.

MisconceptionName: Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we add the equations.

QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing mental multiplication strategies.
Tom says \( 15 \times 42=154 \times 2 \)
Katie says \( 15 \times 42=(15 \times 4)+(15 \times 2) \)
Who is correct?
ConstructName: Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication
MisconceptionName: Does not correctly apply the commutative property of multiplication

QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing mental multiplication strategies.
Tom says \( 15 \times 42=154 \times 2 \)
Katie says \( 15 \times 42=(15 \times 4)+(15 \times 2) \)
Who is correct?
ConstructName: Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication
MisconceptionName: Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication

QuestionText: Here are the first \( 4 \) terms of a linear sequence. ![A sequence of 4 patterns, that are the first 4 terms of a sequence. The first  pattern is a rectangle, made of 3 squares stacked vertically. The second  pattern is an L shape made of 4 squares, it is the same as the first pattern but with 1 square stuck to the right of the square that is at the bottom of the rectangle. The 3rd pattern is an L shape made of 5 squares. It is the same as the 2nd pattern but with 1 more square added to the right of the squares at the bottom. The 4th pattern is an L shape made of 6 squares. It is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 1 more square added to the right of the squares at the bottom ]() How many squares would be in the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term?
ConstructName: Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one
MisconceptionName: Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion

ConstructName: Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places

QuestionText: Which element(s) is/are in \( P^{\prime} \) ? ![A diagram showing a Venn diagram of 2 circles. The left circle is for Set P and contains crisps in its left part, sweets in the intersection. The right circle is for set Q and contains pizza in its right part, sweets in the intersection. Outside of the circles it says chocolate.]()
ConstructName: Identify the regions on a double Venn diagram given in set notation
MisconceptionName: Does not understand set notation for complement (eg. A')

QuestionText: Which element(s) is/are in \( P^{\prime} \) ? ![A diagram showing a Venn diagram of 2 circles. The left circle is for Set P and contains crisps in its left part, sweets in the intersection. The right circle is for set Q and contains pizza in its right part, sweets in the intersection. Outside of the circles it says chocolate.]()
ConstructName: Identify the regions on a double Venn diagram given in set notation
MisconceptionName: Believes that the complement of a set includes any elements which are also in another set.

QuestionText:
Look at the function machine. ![An image of two function machines. The first function machine has x as the input. The first function is divide by 3 and the second is +4. The output is 5. The second function machine is the reverse of the first so now 5 is the input but the two function boxes have been left blank.]() What would be the correct steps to solve this equation?
\(\frac{x}{3}+4=5\)
ConstructName: Solve a linear equation using a function machine
MisconceptionName: Does not reverse the order of operations when finding the input of a function machine

QuestionText: Which number line represents \( -3<x \leq 1 \) ?
ConstructName: Represent a linear inequality in the form a ≤ x ≤ b (and other sign arrangements) on a numberline
CorrectAnswerText: ![A number line with a hollow circle above -3 connected to a filled in circle above 1.]()
WrongAnswerText: ![A number line with a hollow circle above -3 and an arrow coming out of it over the numbers -4, -5 etc and a filled in circle above 1 with an arrow coming out of it over the numbers 2, 3, 4, 5 etc.]()
MisconceptionName: Mixes up greater than and less than symbols

QuestionText: Which number line represents \( -3<x \leq 1 \) ?
ConstructName: Represent a linear inequality in the form a ≤ x ≤ b (and other sign arrangements) on a numberline
CorrectAnswerText: ![A number line with a hollow circle above -3 connected to a filled in circle above 1.]()
WrongAnswerText: ![A number line with a filled in circle above -3 connected to a hollow circle above 1.]()
MisconceptionName: When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning.

QuestionText: Which diagram shows an angle of \( 325^{\circ} \) ?
ConstructName: Use a protractor to measure angles between 270° and 360°
CorrectAnswerText: ![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out a reflex angle. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, clockwise around to the red line that is half way between 40 and 30 (inner scale) and halfway between 140 and 150 (outer scale).]()
WrongAnswerText: ![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out a reflex angle. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, clockwise around to the red line that is half way between 160 and 150 (inner scale) and halfway between 20 and 30 (outer scale).]()
MisconceptionName: Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring obtuse angles

QuestionText: Which diagram shows an angle of \( 325^{\circ} \) ?

CorrectAnswerText: ![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out a reflex angle. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, clockwise around to the red line that is half way between 40 and 30 (inner scale) and halfway between 140 and 150 (outer scale).]()
WrongAnswerText: ![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out a reflex angle. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, clockwise around to the red line that is half way between 30 and 20 (inner scale) and halfway between 150 and 160 (outer scale).]()
MisconceptionName: Chooses the correct scale when measuring angles on a protractor but starts from the wrong number when the angle is in between two labelled dashes

QuestionText: Which diagram shows an angle of \( 325^{\circ} \) ?
ConstructName: Use a protractor to measure angles between 270° and 360°
CorrectAnswerText: ![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out a reflex angle. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, clockwise around to the red line that is half way between 40 and 30 (inner scale) and halfway between 140 and 150 (outer scale).]()
WrongAnswerText: ![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out a reflex angle. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, clockwise around to the red line that is half way between 150 and 140 (inner scale) and halfway between 30 and 40 (outer scale).]()

QuestionText:
Eliza is trying to work out if \( 82 \) is a term in the sequence \( 3 n+1 \)

Below is her working out. What conclusion should Eliza draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 3 n+1 & =82 \\ 3 n & =81 \\ n & =27\end{aligned} \)
ConstructName: Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not
CorrectAnswerText: \( 82 \) is in the sequence and is the \( 27^{\text {th }} \) term
WrongAnswerText: \( 27 \) is in the sequence and is the \( 82^{\text {nd }} \) term
MisconceptionName: Mixes up term in a sequence and position of a term

QuestionText:
Eliza is trying to work out if \( 82 \) is a term in the sequence \( 3 n+1 \)

Below is her working out. What conclusion should Eliza draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 3 n+1 & =82 \\ 3 n & =81 \\ n & =27\end{aligned} \)
ConstructName: Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not
CorrectAnswerText: \( 82 \) is in the sequence and is the \( 27^{\text {th }} \) term
WrongAnswerText: \( 82 \) is not in the sequence because \( 27 \) is an integer
MisconceptionName: Believes the position of a sequence cannot be an integer

QuestionText:
Eliza is trying to work out if \( 82 \) is a term in the sequence \( 3 n+1 \)

Below is her working out. What conclusion should Eliza draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 3 n+1 & =82 \\ 3 n & =81 \\ n & =27\end{aligned} \)
ConstructName: Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not
CorrectAnswerText: \( 82 \) is in the sequence and is the \( 27^{\text {th }} \) term
WrongAnswerText: Eliza's method does not answer this question
MisconceptionName: Does not know how to calculate the position of a term in a sequence

QuestionText:
![Think of a number, then subtract \( 5 \), next divide by \( 8 \), next add 4, and finally multiply by \( 7 \).]() Jo says you can write this as:

\]

QuestionText:
![A grid of 7 squares across and 7 squares up. A red vertical line goes from the bottom to the top of the grid, it is 4 squares left from the edge of the grid. An orange rectangle (3 squares width and 2 squares height) is drawn to the left of the red line, with its right-hand side on the red line.  The bottom side of the rectangle is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid. The bottom left corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter P, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid and 3 squares to the left of the red line. The bottom right corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter Q, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid on the red line. ]() Tom and Katie are discussing reflections

Tom says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( P \) stays in the same position

Katie says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( Q \) stays in the same position
Who is correct?

MisconceptionName: Fails to reflect across mirror line

QuestionText:
Jo and Paul are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:

\)

Who is correct?

MisconceptionName: When solving an equation with a fraction, thinks you don't need to multiply every term on both sides when multiplying by the denominator

QuestionText:

\frac{m}{6}-4=24

QuestionText: John rotates rectangle \( A B C D 90^{\circ} \) clockwise from the centre \( (3,2) \). What error has he made? ![A positive, coordinate grid with two rectangles drawn on it. The rectangle labelled ABCD has the coordinates: A(1,3) B(1,5) C(2,5) and D(2,3). The other rectangle has the coordinates: (4,3) (6,3) (6,2) and (4,2).]()
ConstructName: Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object
CorrectAnswerText: He has used the wrong centre
WrongAnswerText: He has translated by the vector \( \left(\begin{array}{l}3 \\ 2\end{array}\right) \)
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise that a shape translated would not change orientation

QuestionText: John rotates rectangle \( A B C D 90^{\circ} \) clockwise from the centre \( (3,2) \). What error has he made? ![A positive, coordinate grid with two rectangles drawn on it. ConstructName: Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object
CorrectAnswerText: He has used the wrong centre
MisconceptionName: Mixes up clockwise and anticlockwise

Which of the following is the best estimate for the gradient of the curve when \( t=6 \) ![The image is of a velocity-time graph. There is a straight line, a tangent, drawn so that it is touching the curve at t=6. The tangent goes through (2, 31), (6, 47) and (8,55). ]()
ConstructName: Estimate the gradient at a point on a non-linear section of a real life graph
SubjectName: Gradient as change in y over change in x
MisconceptionName: Believes gradient at a point = y coordinate/x coordinate

ConstructName: Recognise other roots of numbers
MisconceptionName: Has multiplied by the root power

ConstructName: Recognise other roots of numbers
MisconceptionName: Does not understand the root power of 4

ConstructName: Recognise other roots of numbers
MisconceptionName: Divides by the order of the root

QuestionText:
\begin{tabular}{llll|l|l}
\( x \) & \( -1 \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) &  & \( -1 \) & 
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( y=x^{2}-x+1 \) What should replace the star?

QuestionText:
What is the gradient of this line?
\(4 x-5 y=20\)
ConstructName: Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c
SubjectName: Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation
MisconceptionName: Believes that the coefficient of x represents the gradient even when a line is not in the form y = mx+c

QuestionText:
What is the gradient of this line?
\(4 x-5 y=20\)
ConstructName: Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c
SubjectName: Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation
MisconceptionName: When solving an equation where there is a negative sign in front of the variable and its equivalent value, assumes the variable has a negative value

QuestionText:
This is a conversion graph between pints and litres.
Which of the following is the best estimate for the number of pints equivalent to \( 50 \) litres? ![A graph on gridded paper showing litres on the y axis from 0 to 50 and pints on the x axis from 0 to 90. A straight line goes from the origin and passes through (35,20) (not marked - just a point it goes through) but extends the whole way up the graph.]()

MisconceptionName: When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.

QuestionText:
This is a conversion graph between pints and litres.
Which of the following is the best estimate for the number of pints equivalent to \( 50 \) litres? ![A graph on gridded paper showing litres on the y axis from 0 to 50 and pints on the x axis from 0 to 90. QuestionText: This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( y=3 x \) ![A table with two rows and two columns. The top left box has 'x', with a star in the top right box. The bottom left box has 'y' with a 9 in the bottom right box. ]() What should replace the star?

QuestionText: This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( y=3 x \) ![A table with two rows and two columns. The top left box has 'x', with a star in the top right box. The bottom left box has 'y' with a 9 in the bottom right box. ]() What should replace the star?

"Describe how you feel when you are about to go on holiday."

What type of data is she collecting by asking this question?

QuestionText:

At what time did he first start travelling at \( 4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \) ? ![The image is of a graph. Its vertical axis labelled Velocity (m/s) and has the scale 0, 2, 4, 6 marked in even steps. Its horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has the scale 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 marked in even steps. 
The graph is in three sections. The first section is a straight slanted line from (0,0) to (1, 4). The second section is a horizontal line from (1, 4) to (3, 4). The third section is a slanted line from (3, 4) to (5, 0).]()

MisconceptionName: When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.

QuestionText: What is the next pattern in this linear sequence? ![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is a rectangle, made of 3 squares stacked vertically. The second pattern is the same as the first pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 1. The 3rd pattern is the same as the second pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 2. The 4th pattern is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 3.]()
ConstructName: Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern
CorrectAnswerText: ![This pattern is made up of 11 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then an extra square on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()
WrongAnswerText: ![This pattern is the same as Pattern 4: it is made up of 9 squares as a 4 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then an extra square on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns

QuestionText: What is the next pattern in this linear sequence? ![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is a rectangle, made of 3 squares stacked vertically. The second pattern is the same as the first pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 1. The 3rd pattern is the same as the second pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 2. The 4th pattern is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 3.]()
ConstructName: Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern
CorrectAnswerText: ![This pattern is made up of 11 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then an extra square on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()
WrongAnswerText: ![This pattern is made up of 12 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then 2 extra squares on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns

QuestionText: What is the next pattern in this linear sequence? ![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is a rectangle, made of 3 squares stacked vertically. The second pattern is the same as the first pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 1. The 3rd pattern is the same as the second pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 2. The 4th pattern is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 3.]()
ConstructName: Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern
CorrectAnswerText: ![This pattern is made up of 11 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then an extra square on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()

QuestionText: Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
ConstructName: For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine
CorrectAnswerText:
![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "+ 3" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "3 + 2p" written inside it.
 The second function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has  "+ 3" written inside the next rectangle, "✕ 2"  written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2(3 + p)" written inside it.]()
WrongAnswerText:
![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "+ 3" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "3 + 2p" written inside it.
 The second function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has  "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "+ 3"  written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2(3 + p)" written inside it.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.

QuestionText:
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
4, \quad 10, \quad 28, \quad 82, \quad \ldots
\]

CorrectAnswerText: To get the next term you multiply the previous term by \( 3 \) and subtract \( 2 \)
WrongAnswerText: To get the next term you add \( 6 \) to the previous term
MisconceptionName: Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule

QuestionText:
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
4, \quad 10, \quad 28, \quad 82, \quad \ldots
\]
ConstructName: Describe a term-to-term sequence
CorrectAnswerText: To get the next term you multiply the previous term by \( 3 \) and subtract \( 2 \)
WrongAnswerText: To get the next term you double the previous term and add \( 2 \)
MisconceptionName: Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule

QuestionText: This is how Teddy calculates the answer to \( 600 \div 25 \) mentally "There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in 100. I then multiplied \( 4 \) by \( 6 \) to get \( 24 \). So \( 600 \) divided by \( 25 \) is \( 24 \)" Teddy uses the same method to calculate \( 800 \div 25 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?
ConstructName: Recognise and use efficient methods for mental division
CorrectAnswerText:
There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \) 
Then I multiplied \( 4 \) by \( 8 \) 
So the answer is \( 32 \)
WrongAnswerText:
There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \) 
Then I multiplied \( 8 \) by \( 6 \) 
So the answer is \( 48 \)
MisconceptionName: Does not copy a given method accurately

QuestionText:
Dave has recorded the number of pets his classmates have in the frequency table on the right. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of pets & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} How many people did Dave record the results of?
ConstructName: Interpret numbers in a frequency table
MisconceptionName: Mistakes the number of rows for the total frequency in a frequency table

QuestionText: Which of the following best describes how to construct an angle of \( 60^{\circ} \) using a ruler and a pair of compasses?
ConstructName: Construct an angle of 60° using a ruler and a compass
CorrectAnswerText:
- Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width equal to the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line 
- Draw a straight line from the ends of each line to where the arcs intersect
WrongAnswerText:
- Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width at least the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line and below from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line 
- Join up where the lines intersect
MisconceptionName: Believes constructing a perpendicular gives an angle of 60 degrees

QuestionText:
![A grid of 8 squares across and 7 squares up.  A blue isosceles triangle, labelled "P", is drawn on the grid. Its corners are at points: 4 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid; 2 squares right and 3 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid; 2 squares right and 5 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid.   Another blue isosceles triangle (identical shape and size to P), labelled "Q", is also drawn on the grid. Its corners are at points: 6 squares right and 3 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid; 6 squares right and 5 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid; 8 squares right and 4 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid.
A light blue vertical line, labelled "A" goes from top to bottom of the grid, 2 squares to the right of the left-hand side of the grid. A dark blue vertical line, labelled "B" goes from top to bottom of the grid, 4 squares to the right of the left-hand side of the grid. A green vertical line, labelled "C" goes from top to bottom of the grid, 5 squares to the right of the left-hand side of the grid. ]() Which is the correct line of reflection to map triangle \( \mathrm{P} \) to triangle \( \mathrm{Q} \) ?
ConstructName: Describe a reflection in a vertical line by drawing the line of reflection, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
MisconceptionName: Believes a line of reflection must be touching the original shape

QuestionText: Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a exponential function?

SubjectName: Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x
CorrectAnswerText: ![A curved graph that starts just above the x-axis on the left and travels right and very gradually up. Just before it reaches the y-axis it travels more steeply up and right, going through a point on the y-axis above the origin and continually steeply rising up and right.]()
WrongAnswerText: ![A graph with two curves, in the top right and bottom left quadrants. The top right curves starts up and right of the origin and travels steeply down and right, it then levels off to travel alongside the x-axis without touching it. The bottom left curve starts down and left of the origin, travels steeply up and left, it then levels off just below the x-axis without touching it.]()
MisconceptionName: Confuses reciprocal and exponential graphs

QuestionText: Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a exponential function?
ConstructName: Recognise an exponential graph from its shape
SubjectName: Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x
CorrectAnswerText: ![A curved graph that starts just above the x-axis on the left and travels right and very gradually up. Just before it reaches the y-axis it travels more steeply up and right, going through a point on the y-axis above the origin and continually steeply rising up and right.]()
WrongAnswerText: ![A curved graph that starts in the top left, travels steeply down and right, turns to travel steeply up and right, to the origin, where it turns around to travel down and right again.]()

ConstructName: Recognise an exponential graph from its shape
SubjectName: Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x
CorrectAnswerText: ![A curved graph that starts just above the x-axis on the left and travels right and very gradually up. Just before it reaches the y-axis it travels more steeply up and right, going through a point on the y-axis above the origin and continually steeply rising up and right.]()

\hline \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) & \( 12 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 8 \) \\

Jo and Paul are arguing about rounding.

QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing rearranging \( t=\sqrt{u+9} \) to make \( u \) the subject
Tom says a correct first line of working could be: \( t=\sqrt{u}+3 \)
Katie says a correct first line of working could be: \( t^{2}=u+9 \)
Who is correct?
ConstructName: Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and three or more steps are needed
MisconceptionName: Thinks that the square root of an expression square roots each term in the expression, rather than square rooting the whole expression

QuestionText: When factorising \( x^{2}+6 x+8 \) we need two numbers that:

QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing this sequence. ![The first 3 patterns in a sequence are shown. The first pattern is a blue rectangle with 6 yellow circles attached to its perimeter: 2 circles on each of the longer sides and 1 circle on each of the shorter sides. 
Pattern 2 is made up of 2 blue rectangles, attached together in a row by their short edges. There are also 10 yellow circles in this pattern, attached to the perimeter of the rectangles: 2 circles on every longer side of each rectangle and 1 circle on each of the two free shorter sides (i.e. that are not attached to the other rectangle). 
Pattern 3 is made up of 3 blue rectangles, attached together in a row by their short edges. There are also 14 yellow circles in this pattern, attached to the perimeter of the rectangles: 2 circles on every longer side of each rectangle and 1 circle on each of the two free shorter sides (i.e. that are not attached to another rectangle).]() Tom says the number of circles in the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term will be 
double the number of circles in the \( 5^{\text {th }} \) term.

Katie says the number of rectangles in the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term will be 
double the number of rectangles in the \( 5^{\text {th }} \) term.

Who do you agree with?
ConstructName: Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one
MisconceptionName: Believes there is a multiplicative relationship between values of terms in a linear sequence e.g. 10th term is double 5th term

QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{24}{x}=6
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 24=6 x \) 

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( 24=\frac{x}{6} \)

Who is correct?
ConstructName: Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers
MisconceptionName: When solving an equation with x in the denominator, thinks the inverse operation is to make it the numerator on the other side

QuestionText: Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (2,-5) \) and \( (-7,1) \) She labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{cccc}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (2, & -5) & (-7, & 1)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the first bracket equal?

QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}3 x-2 y=15 \\ x+2 y=20\end{array} \) Tom says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct?

 The second function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has  "−3" written inside the next rectangle, "✕ 2"  written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2(p − 3)" written inside it.]()

QuestionText:

QuestionText:

\hline \( 19 \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline \( 20 \) & \( 1 \) & \\

The top right curves starts up and right of the origin and travels steeply down and right, it then levels off to travel alongside the x-axis without touching it. The bottom left curve starts down and left of the origin, travels steeply up and left, it then levels off just below the x-axis without touching it.]()
WrongAnswerText: ![A curved graph that starts just above the x-axis on the left and travels right and very gradually up. Just before it reaches the y-axis it travels more steeply up and right, going through a point on the y-axis above the origin and continually steeply rising up and right. ]()

QuestionText: Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (1,-6) \) and \( (-5,2) \) She labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{rrrr}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (1, & -6) & (-5, & 2)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the second bracket equal?
ConstructName: Substitute negative integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots
MisconceptionName: Believes subtraction is commutative

QuestionText: Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (1,-6) \) and \( (-5,2) \) She labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{rrrr}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (1, & -6) & (-5, & 2)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the second bracket equal?
ConstructName: Substitute negative integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots
MisconceptionName: When subtracting a negative number from a positive number, uses a method which assumes one of the negative signs can be ignored

WrongAnswerText: ![A column addition of 0.7 + 0.54. The 0 of 0.7 is directly above the decimal point of 0.54, the decimal point of 0.7 is directly above the 5 of 0.54 and the 7 of 0.7 is directly above the 4 of 0.54.]()
MisconceptionName: Thinks that when adding decimals with a different number of decimal places, you should line up the digits to the right

QuestionText: Which of the following best describes how to construct a triangle with side length \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) with angles of \( 40^{\degree} \) and \( 50^{\degree} \) either side?
ConstructName: Construct a triangle using Angle-Side-Angle
CorrectAnswerText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the other end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle
WrongAnswerText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the same end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle
MisconceptionName: Draws both angles at the same end of the line when constructing a triangle

QuestionText: John walks from home at a constant speed to a bench, stops for a rest, and then runs home at a constant speed. Which of the following displacement \( (d) \) time \( (t) \) graphs is most likely to illustrate John's journey?
ConstructName: Given a situation sketch an appropriate displacement-time graph
CorrectAnswerText:
![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with gentle, positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is a sloped line with very steep negative gradient that ends when it touches the horizontal axis.]()
WrongAnswerText:
![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with steep, positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is a sloped line with gentle, negative gradient that ends when it touches the horizontal axis.]()
MisconceptionName: Believes a less steep gradient corresponds to a faster speed

QuestionText: John walks from home at a constant speed to a bench, stops for a rest, and then runs home at a constant speed. Which of the following displacement \( (d) \) time \( (t) \) graphs is most likely to illustrate John's journey?
ConstructName: Given a situation sketch an appropriate displacement-time graph
CorrectAnswerText:
![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with gentle, positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is a sloped line with very steep negative gradient that ends when it touches the horizontal axis.]()
WrongAnswerText:
![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is another sloped line with a steeper positive gradient.]()
MisconceptionName: Believes displacement continues to increase even when returning to starting point

QuestionText:
What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
 Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p+2 q=12 \\
3 p+2 q=8
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p-2 q=12 \\
3 p-2 q=8
\end{array}
\)
ConstructName: Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable
MisconceptionName: Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we do the operation matching the sign (+ if positive, - if negative)

QuestionText:
What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
 Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p+2 q=12 \\
3 p+2 q=8
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p-2 q=12 \\
3 p-2 q=8
\end{array}
\)
ConstructName: Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable
MisconceptionName: Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we add the equations.

QuestionText:
What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
 Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p+2 q=12 \\
3 p+2 q=8
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p-2 q=12 \\
3 p-2 q=8
\end{array}
\)
ConstructName: Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable
MisconceptionName: Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we do the operation inverse to the sign (- if positive, + if negative)

WrongAnswerText: Sam has not moved right the correct number of places
MisconceptionName: When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.

QuestionText: Sam has translated the red flag \( \left(\begin{array}{l}2 \\ 3\end{array}\right) \) ![Image showing two identical shapes on a coordinate grid. The red shape has the point (2,1) and the corresponding point on the blue shape is (4,3).]() What error has Sam made?

MisconceptionName: Confuses the number of regions in a Venn diagram as the total number of entries in the diagram

QuestionText:
All the students in a class were asked if they have a brother, sister, both or none.

MisconceptionName: Forgets to include values outside of the Venn diagram when finding the total

QuestionText:

\( (t) \).

Which of the following does that \( 0.8 \) best represent? ![A sketch of a graph with s on the y axis and t on the x axis. A straight line slopes upwards from the origin 2/3 of the way up the graph, 1/5 across the graph. It then becomes horizontal for the next 1/5 of the graph, before sloping downwards in a straight line for the remainder of the graph. ]()
ConstructName: Interpret the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph
CorrectAnswerText: Jadon is decelerating at a rate of \( 0.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \)
WrongAnswerText: Jadon is travelling at a speed of \( 0.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
MisconceptionName: Believes the gradient of a speed-time graph is the speed
